text: Detail from Nicolaes Visscher , Novissima et Accuratissima Totius Americae Descriptio , c . 1658 ( plate 1 ) . Over the course of the early modern period , the ‘ NN ’ of the Netherlands opened up in several productive ways . Perhaps most famously , the Dutch created the JJ NN of the Republic : viable political NN , demarcated from an older collection of provinces , which had been gathered most recently under the auspices of the king of Spain . The Dutch RB expended tremendous effort reconstituting the physical NN of the Low NNPS : land reclaimed from NN and increased urban centres , which allowed the Republic to grow in population and gain in arable terrain . And the Dutch enlarged their commercial and colonial NN by dint of their numerous overseas expansions : a ‘ NNP ’ Netherland ( almost always referred to in singular form ) , which arose on the eastern shores of what was already then called North America ; a modern ‘ Batavia ’ , which emerged in present‐day Indonesia ; and a host of Dutch forts and settlements that otherwise dotted the coasts and islands of Asia , Africa and the Americas . The Dutch RB developed , just as famously , JJ pictorial devices to engage with NN – the painterly and printerly techniques explored in this issue – and , not unrelated , JJ techniques to map spaces : the most robust cartographic ateliers of early modern Europe , which developed RB in Antwerp and then in Amsterdam from the late sixteenth century , coincident with the rise of the Dutch Republic and the Golden Age of Dutch visual culture . Maps proliferated in the early modern Netherlands . They offered a means both to delineate NN and to narrate NN – to explicate how NN works and to assert where their makers ( and consumers ) fit within these spaces . Yet maps were RB important and ubiquitous material objects in the Netherlands , which occupied myriad additional spaces and which played with the JJ spatial and material concerns of their viewers . They engaged viewers and enticed them into their interpretive spaces . How do Dutch maps work , and what does this reveal about the visual culture of the early modern Netherlands ? These questions were famously tackled by Svetlana Alpers in The Art of Describing mostly in regard to landscape painting . Yet in JJ ways , her influential essay on ‘ The Mapping Impulse in Dutch Art ’ – the NN ‐to source for non ‐Dutch specialists , particularly historians of NN who seek to affiliate their concerns with habits of natural ‐history representation with a broadly northern European tradition of painting – curiously avoided the key to this intriguing interpretive palace : the maps themselves and how they actually function . 1 While Alpers ’ oft‐cited chapter does open with Vermeer 's Allegory of Painting and the impressive wall map by Claes Jansz . Visscher that amply fills its background , maps are otherwise relegated to the side , treated sparingly and elliptically at best – at least the form of artfully designed , lavishly embellished and meticulously printed maps that enjoyed such phenomenal popularity in the Netherlands from the late sixteenth through at least the early eighteenth century . Maps do matter , and , as Alpers astutely points out , cartographic materials played a significant and instructive role in the visual , JJ and indeed the political culture of the early modern Dutch Republic . They were ubiquitous in more ways than CD : as décor in houses and paintings ; as devices of learning and JJ standing ; as NN of cultural and political messaging . In a vital sense , however , these roles remain conspicuously absent in her analysis , inadequately problematized and not at all ‘ deconstructed ’ – to invoke the language of the JJ critical cartography that was being developed precisely when Alpers was formulating her insights into Dutch visual culture . 2 Maps as productive sources ( as opposed to theorized ‘ impulses ’ ) are only lightly glossed in Alpers ’ essay , their most superficial features brought to bear on a , by contrast , highly sophisticated argument about forms of ‘ mapped ’ landscapes ( as she terms it ) , best exemplified by the JJ panoramic paintings of Philips Koninck . This inverted theoretical focus distorts our perspective of Dutch ( and other ) maps and relegates to the periphery an enormously dynamic visual source in the early modern Netherlands . It RB irons out – unnecessarily – the stimulating complexities of cartographic sources and the promising possibilities of Alpers ’ implied query : what do maps offer to scholars of Dutch visual culture ? Rather than a ‘ JJ working NN ’ , a Dutch map of this period was typically dense and jagged , presenting the viewer with multiple angles of interpretive entry , as the essays of this issue show for other NN and genres . Rather than offering a ‘ detached or perhaps RB … culturally unbiased view ’ – can such a source ever be possible ? – these profusely layered artefacts furnish critical insight into and material evidence of the visual culture that Alpers aims to address . 3 Early modern maps are delightfully thick objects and fundamentally material things . They illustrate modes of representation and craft , and they encourage various points of vision and interpretation . As it turns out , maps are anything but ‘ JJ ’ . They richly demonstrate , in their own NN , the ‘ picturing impulse ’ of early modern Dutch culture . This brief intervention aims not so much to argue with Alpers as to consider a part of her argument that was left relatively under‐scrutinized : the workings of Dutch maps . My goal is less to analyse how these maps work – there is a vast and expanding literature that does just that4 – or RB how they work in the context of early modern Dutch painting , but rather to explore the qualities of cartographic design that might speak to the thematics of seeing and sensing pictures , so that they might contribute , in this NN , to the broader understanding of Dutch visual culture that this issue sets out to explore . Maps are indubitably thick : they gesture relentlessly toward their materiality and to the challenge their makers face in rendering into CD dimensions what begins as three – the same challenge confronted by Dutch painters , as several of the essays gathered here so elegantly argue . Maps are theatrical : they stage JJ NN in a profusely embellished form – they rarely offer mere , austere ‘ description ’ – and they dramatize for their viewers ways of processing both the lands and waters of the NN and the things and events that occur within them . And – as this might imply – maps are narrational : they narrate spaces , frame histories and posit polemics – much IN Baroque theatre , to be sure , yet RB IN genres of painting of the period , both in the Netherlands and elsewhere . To demonstrate a few of these qualities , I turn , naturally , to a map : Nicolaes Visscher 's immensely popular Novissima et Accuratissima Totius Americae Descriptio ( JJ edition c . 1658 ; plate 1 ) , published more or less contemporaneously with Vermeer 's Allegory of Painting ( c . 1666–68 ) . Visscher 's printed map has an impressive history , VBG backward and forward , and touching as well the key cartographic source of Alpers ’ inquiry . 5 Its original author was the only son of Claes Jansz . Visscher , the well ‐regarded cartographer who engraved the wall map depicted in the Vermeer Allegory . The Visscher family RB had ties by marriage to the illustrious Hondius firm , makers of the Mercator atlases through the JJ half of the seventeenth century – they were thus kinsmen of mapping aristocracy – and their atelier in Amsterdam on the Kalverstraat placed them in the thick of all things cartographic . The younger Visscher followed in his father 's professional footsteps and enjoyed considerable success , especially with his map of the Americas . The Americae went through several editions , RB in revised forms engraved by other ( sometimes competing ) ateliers ; it was appropriated for geography books , both as an insert and ( in a distilled form ) as a frontispiece ; and it was routinely copied and pirated outright , extending its successful run well into the eighteenth century . 6 It became perhaps the single most important early modern map of the western hemisphere and certainly CD of the most recognized images of the NNP NNP . Its allegorical ( lower ) cartouche , moreover , became the all ‐but standard representation of ‘ America ’ , an iconic image that crossed easily into other genres and NN . Nevertheless , despite its prestigious lineage and its titular promises of ‘ novelty ’ and ‘ accuracy ’ , the map succeeded not so much for its exacting ‘ description ’ as for other , arguably pictorial reasons : for its highly embellished and appealing presentation of the NNP NNP . The actual cartographic content of the map – the particular delineations of the lands and seas of the western hemisphere – was scarcely JJ . It derived mostly from older materials , chiefly Joan Blaeu 's 1648 map of the NN ; the outlines of the continents of these CD maps are nearly identical . This habit of replication was not at all uncommon in early modern Dutch cartography ( as in other graphic arts ) , especially in the sort of lavishly ornamented charts that became the mainstay of Amsterdam ateliers . Nor can the Visscher map make great claims for geographic meticulousness : a prominent ‘ California ’ floats off the western coast of America , an island of the mapmakers ’ imagination ; the Great Lakes blend into CD truly great lake , which leaks its contents into the Atlantic ; and the JJ ‐sought Northwest Passage is offered optimistically as readily accessible , an open NN flowing freely into Asia . The map 's promise of novelty and accuracy , in other words , is rhetoric – again , a fairly common ploy in early modern mapping ( as in late modern advertising ) . No Baconian empiricism here , but rather strategies that relate to the techniques of rhetoric – pervasive across myriad Renaissance fields of enquiry – and to the crafty practices of the workshop . What likely sold the map , more than its less ‐than ‐meticulous ‘ description ’ of the continents , MD have been the staging of the Americae and the ample ‘ adornments ’ that enriched Visscher 's product : the four‐legged staffage that wander the open , ultimately uncharted spaces of the map ( what J. B. Harley famously called its ‘ silences ’ ) ; the ethnographic vignettes that explicate the NNP NNP 's indigenes ; and , not least , the superb cartouches that fill the upper and lower divisions of the vast Pacific NNP , at once distilling and framing the continents in terms of NN and narrative . 7 The charming ‘ creatures in the map ’ – these did not VB out of style in the Renaissance – MD have appealed to a range of consumers . 8 CD handsome stag deer saunter across the terrain of Eastern Canada ( Nova Francia on the map ) ; they MD appear to await the hunter 's arrow just as do the tame deer of Ben Johnson 's poetic Penshurst or any other exemplary country house . A fox gambols across the Great Plains ( a scene likewise redolent of the Northern European countryside ) ; and beavers , coveted lately by Dutch merchants for their valuable pelts , pose obediently just inland of the plainly demarcated empire of Nieu [ NNP ] Nederland .9 Further afield a pair of brown bears inhabit the open , wild west ; meanwhile , a lone anteater has South America largely to himself . The two‐legged staffage of tropical America – that is , the indigenous Americans – do no hunt any exotic fauna , but CD another . Their depiction in the interior of Brazil , naked and engrossed in brutal warfare , offers a synoptic view of the ‘ savage ’ Indian , here imagined as uncivilized if RB unobtrusive . As for the pair of cartouches , CD occupying the upper left and the other the lower left portion of Visscher 's print , these serve as the dual anchors of the map , the dominant pictorial elements and the keys to the artefact 's interpretation ( plate 2 and plate 3 ) . They RB function to stage the map 's motifs and – crucially – to elucidate its overall message . It is here that both the theatrical and narrative impulses of Dutch mapping come through most vividly and most pictorially . Both cartouches follow designs by Nicolaes Pietersz . Berchem , a highly regarded landscape painter , as it turns out ( and the only son of Pieter Claesz , a master of still ‐life painting ) , who specialized in a form of idealized Italianate scenes popular in that period ( a subgenre of Dutch landscape that lay conspicuously beyond Alpers ’ scrutiny as putatively un ‐Dutch ) . 10 The pair of map vignettes work as an ensemble – the device of the parasol lures the viewer 's eye from the vignette below to the balancing scene above – yet it is the iconic figure of America herself , who gracefully gestures to the map 's ‘ carved ’ title , that lies at the heart of the visual programme . Berchem at once allegorized and condensed the essential qualities of the cartographic NN . He packed it all in : the alluring personification of ‘ America ’ , decked out in a dainty feathered skirt and colourful feathered headdress ; the pearls , barely visible around her neck , demonstrating the region 's endemic richness ; the classic bow and arrow , just to her NN , alluding to her habit of hunting ( America RB bears a stylized club ) ; the mounds of freshly mined gold ( or perhaps silver ) piling up at her NNS , alongside stacks of ingots that indicate the substantial mineral wealth of the continent ; a pair of queerly coiled snakes , which reveal the exotic naturalia of the NNP NNP ; and the central parasol , which shades America 's head from the tropical sun.11 The sum of the parts tells the NN of the whole : a massively rich , vaguely exotic , not ‐quite‐tamed NNP NNP . The upper cartouche furnishes another allegory , which introduces a different angle on America , yet CD that is thematically complementary . A cluster of figures surrounds and supports a free‐floating , shield ‐like device , which bears a patron 's coat of arms and the map 's dedication ( to Cornelius Witsen , a major supporter of overseas trade and exploration , on the original NN , yet this varies with different printings ) . 12 The predominant figure of this cluster , a European woman hovering in the very upper‐left corner of the map , represents Christian Faith : relatively plainly dressed , she points didactically with CD hand to a cross that she holds in her other hand and positions directly above the other figures . She glances not to the cross , however , but to a broad ‐shouldered , sharp‐taloned , demon ‐like figure below , who tumbles out of the sky : an allegory of diabolism , ejected by the Christian Church . An angel opposite and above gazes , mouth agape , at this falling devil and the wondrous turn of events , while another heavenly figure , just to the angel 's left , announces per clarion the plunge of diabolism and the spread of the gospel . Finally , an Indian – the figure situated closest to the American landmass who wears the same feathered headdress as the principal ‘ American ’ figure of the lower cartouche , in this NN linking the CD vignettes – gazes in astonishment at the allegory of Faith , whose good works have apparently converted him . The cartouche recounts , in short , the Church 's labours in the NNP NNP : its presumed successes casting out false faiths and diabolisms , and evangelizing among the American indigenes .13 To say that these vignettes are staged is to identify both the drama of Faith 's triumphs in the NNP NNP and the several marks of theatricality that hold the ensemble together . The parasol does this formally : not only does it lure the eye upward , but it points directly to the upper Indian ; were he to fall from the sky , he might pierce himself on the parasol 's tasselled spike . The parasol functions , further , as a clever stage prop , a showy accoutrement that establishes the ostentatious tropicality of America ( the point of the parasol abuts the very words ‘ Tropicus Capricorni ’ ) . In fact , bona fide parasols commonly served as props in Baroque theatre ; and a particularly famous example of this , the engraving of Anne Bracegirdle in her popular role as ‘ The Indian Queen ’ , alludes subtly to the Berchem allegory of America : feathers , pearls and parasol render the renowned Restoration actress adequately ‘ exotic ’ . 14 Theatrical motions – of hands and other limbs – RB lend the joint cartouches a dramatic , balletic cogency : arms akimbo on either side of the title slab , hands gesturing instructively by the allegorical figures both above and below , and the scissoring NNS of Christian Faith and her Indian protégé alike all serve to animate the scene . The swirling dress of Faith , swept up by the heavenly winds , and her billowing and entirely theatrical shawl ( since this prop MD have been utterly extraneous in the heavens ) suggest , yet again , tricks of the stage – and , of course , of highly painterly composition . All of these devices heighten the drama of the map and thereby elucidate the meaning of America . And all of these devices might RB prompt the question : what is the message of the map and the narrative arch that bridges Berchem 's upper and lower cartouches ? The bond between Faith and America harks RB to a proverbial wisdom that circulated in late medieval and early modern Europe about the inverse relation of ‘ NN ’ and ‘ gold ’ : wherever the latter flowed abundantly , it was proposed , the former was typically scarce ( and the reverse ) . Such a conception of America and her endemic riches ‐cum ‐heathenism justified much of Habsburg Spain 's early colonial action in the NNP NNP – the conquest and simultaneous conversion of the Indians . Yet it RB carried an implicit moral message , which gained traction among critics of the Habsburg Conquista , especially in Northern Europe . And here we need to turn to a text , CD of JJ that MD have helped viewers read Visscher 's map . A late sixteenth ‐century poem , which captioned the Dutch and German editions of an engraved allegory of America , commented poignantly on this contradictory relationship between the European NN and American gold ( words that punned RB more in the original : NN and goud in Dutch ) : Here the wondrous mineral wealth of America fosters her own decline ; she goes from benighted idolatry to miserable slavery . The sixteenth ‐century allegory ( engraved by Adriaen Collaert after a design by Maarten de Vos ) expresses sympathy for the doubly abused Indians . In the Visscher map , however , with its relatively neutral ‐looking figure of Faith , not obviously Catholic nor Protestant , and with its pan‐colonial vision of the Americas – NNP France , NNP Netherlands , and English ‐settled Virginia are all engraved into the NN , no less than the nomenclature of Iberian colonial possessions in South America – the message pertains to European colonialism and European exoticism writ JJ . The map spells out the evangelical and imperial rise of the Old NNP in the NNP . A map , however , RB while it MD possess plentiful text and RB while it might be read as and with the NN of text , is certainly not identical to text – it is textual and pictorial , not to mention cartographical . It is RB material , of course , and while there MD have been textual and iconographic foundations for such maps as Visscher 's , there were RB unmistakable evocations of craft and materiality . The heritage of early modern Dutch cartography goes RB not so much to Ptolemy , as Alpers argues , as to the pioneering labours of Gerard Mercator and Abraham Ortelius , who drew on the traditions of late ‐medieval mapping – highly pictorial and allegorical products , typically emanating from the workshops of master illuminators – and on the NN of craft . 16 Ortelius instinctively placed geography in the context of art : famously in relationship to history ( ‘ Historiae oculus geographia ’ ) , yet RB in the sphere of drama . 17 His Theatrum orbis terrarrum not only summons the language of the stage , but RB greets its audience on its engraved title page with a recognizable proscenium ( plate 4 ) . Mercator – whose posthumously published atlas RB adapted the symbols of theatre on its title page – sprang more directly from the milieu of craft . His main source of income in his early professional NNS came from the fabrication of mathematical and navigational instruments – this placed him in the vibrant , metal ‐working ateliers of northern Europe – and , for JJ of the early cartographic projects with which we associate him ( his work with Gemma Frisius and Gaspar à Myrica , for example , on their terrestrial globe ) , he served as a highly skilled engraver of brass plates . He was RB an innovator in the production of commercial globes ; and he was a remarkable italicist , who composed , designed and printed the JJ instruction book of italic script published north of the Alps . He mastered math and craft , art and ‘ NN ’ . More to the point , the actual , tangible maps of Mercator and Ortelius VBP out of their NN in these early NNS to emphasize their affiliation with modes of craft and material arts . Both mapmakers ’ ateliers , in producing the JJ generation of ‘ craft maps ’ – this is the geographer John Pickles ’ term for the highly pictorial , thickly ornamented maps that developed in the late sixteenth ‐century Netherlands18 – make habitual reference to the process of their maps ’ production and to the material arts whence they came . Thus does Mercator 's Orbis Terrae Compendiosa Descriptio make literal reference to its maker 's background in brass ‐work by the depiction of an armillary sphere in the upper centre of the map 's design , while RB making more figurative allusions to metalwork in the strapwork surrounding the armillary ; in the elaborate fretwork bearing the JJ hemispheres ; and in the clever metallic tooling of the engraved frame that encases the NN map ( plate 5 ) . These devices serve to emphasize the ‘ thickness ’ of early modern cartography – its broader project of converting three ‐dimensional NN into CD – while RB invoking the material arts with which Mercator ( and JJ map illuminators before him ) sought to affiliate himself . Thus , too , does Ortelius offer CD of his most celebrated cartographic images – Abrahami Patriarchae Peregrinatio et Vita ( 1590 ) , which charts the NN and journeys of the Old Testament patriarch Abraham , the mapmaker 's namesake – as a trompe l'oeil that invokes the illustrious art of tapestry ( plate 6 ) . Meanwhile , several other graphic techniques make more subtle gestures to various other material arts : twenty ‐two circular medallion vignettes , so ‐called since they evoke the bronze medallions much in fashion at that NN , do the heavy ‐lifting narration of Abraham 's NN ; CD superb cartouches display the map 's textual apparatus and once again reference the art of strapwork ( the interior sample with garlands being a particularly fine example of the genre ) ; and CD decorative masks – ‘ hung ’ on a strapwork cartouche , which is ‘ fastened ’ to a cartographic tapestry – not only lend a sense of depth to this already densely materialized map , but RB allude to the NN of theatre . The map , in short , offers a tour de force of spatial manipulation – to VB along with its textual and pictorial narration . Some three ‐quarters of a century later , Nicolaes Visscher and Nicolaes Berchem likewise expended considerable effort in thickening their map . They collaboratively layered several illusions of NN in the Americae engraving . Careful hatching around the edges of the continents and scattered islands lends a sense of depth to the hemisphere , a quality further enhanced by the ‘ shadows ’ cast by the ships at NN and the animals on shore ( VB plate 1 ) . This imparts to what otherwise might be perceived as JJ geographic NN the property of density , and it grants the map 's viewers an optical sense of verticality , as if they were observing the continents from an elevated , almost atmospheric altitude . The swirling figures of the upper vignette induce a dizzying lateral movement yet further up ; we are now in the skies , if not quite the heavens , where shadow and wind still persist ( VB plate 3 ) . The curling ( upper ) cartouche , which carries the map 's dedication on the form of a wooden shield , RB plays with the materiality of that shield : a shield bears a shield , as it were . In the lower vignette , NN moves more horizontally . Here there is a quality of earthiness , as opposed to the lofty airiness above , and the conceit that the ground slopes downward along with the figures behind the ‘ slab ’ of cartouche who recede gently into the horizon ( and presumably further into the subterranean mines from where America 's gold and silver originate ) ( VB plate 2 ) . And if wind animates the upper scene , the sun plays that role below , casting shadows over the figure of America , thereby RB accentuating the tropical heat of the land . The parasol , that most tangible of accessories of the tropics and theatre alike , stylishly shields ‘ America ’ from the elements , and in this NN RB pulls the narrative spaces together . Craft maps , a genre developed outstandingly in the picture‐rich culture of the early modern Netherlands , drew from the arts of painting and engraving , and from the fields of geography and the material arts . Their form owed much to the practices of ateliers : to printerly habits of delineating and ‘ describing ’ , to be sure , yet RB to modes of narrating and embellishing NN , of crafting and thickening maps . Indeed , within the intricate matrix of early modern Dutch workshops , the makers of maps borrowed as well as loaned ; images from cartographic sources and geography books moved from printed NN ( textual as well as iconographic ) , yet RB to material arts . ‘ America ’ MD redeploy over the coming decades from maps to forms of tapestry , ceramic ( especially porcelain , once Europe mastered its own techniques of production ) , lacquer ‐ware , cut glass , and so on , as the image steadily gained in popularity . Visscher 's cartographic images , in other words , moved from the CD ‐dimensional NN of the map RB to the three ‐dimensional NN of the decorative arts from where Mercator and Ortelius had drawn their earlier inspiration . Both the lineage and the influence of ‘ craft ’ maps are rich in numerous ways . Early modern Dutch maps are anything but mere ‘ description ’ , and they most certainly illustrate , pace Alpers , abundant ‘ pictorial marks of [ JJ and political ] authority ’ . CD They illustrate and narrate and dramatize much more , and much that speaks rather productively to Alpers ’ and our concerns with Dutch visual culture . For maps such as those produced by Visscher and his contemporaries ask us – just as other prints and paintings do – to VB about NN and its representation . Dutch maps use graphic forms and pictorial devices to stage NN and to present the drama of NN from multiple angles and perspectives . Visscher 's map , complemented by Berchem 's vignettes , displays the drama of European expansion from up high and down low , from the fauna‐rich interiors of the American continents to the ship ‐peppered seas that surround them . It invokes the tricks of theatre – rhetoric and gesture , evocation and insinuation , props and propaganda – to narrate NN , in this case the spaces of European conquest , colonialism and empire . And it narrates that NN in assorted ways , just as history narrates and as other textual and pictorial genres narrate : to be the eye of history is not necessarily to be wholly mute ( or purely descriptive ) . It does all this , again as other visual sources do , as a means to entice its viewers . The Americae beckon in myriad ways : Berchem 's figure of ‘ America ’ seduces its viewer with her opulent pearls and exotic feathers , tactile prompts of supreme allure ; Visscher 's sheet map invokes multiple registers of materiality , encouraging an intense sense of touch , depth and NN ; and the Americae , of course , arouse wide ‐ranging colonial desires , which surely reached across to several early modern European aspirants of imperial worlds . text: The Great Pyramid is a true masterpiece and has rightly earned the title of a “ Wonder ” . It was built with such precision that our current technology cannot replicate it . Historical analysis shows that the Pyramids were built between 2589 and 2504 BC . There are so JJ interesting facts about this Pyramid that it baffles archaeologists , NNS , astronomers and tourists . Here are the facts : 01 . The pyramid is estimated to have around 2,300,000 stone blocks that weigh from 2 to 30 tons each and there are RB some blocks that weigh over 50 tons . 02 . The Pyramid of Menkaure , the Pyramid of Khafre and the Great Pyramid of Khufu are precisely aligned with the Constellation of Orion . 03 . The base of the pyramid covers 55,000 m2 ( 592,000 ft 2 ) with each side greater than 20,000 m2 ( 218,000 ft2 ) in area . 04 . The interior temperature is constant and equals the average temperature of the NN , 20 Degrees Celsius ( 68 Degrees Fahrenheit ) . 05 . The outer mantle was composed of 144,000 casing stones , all of them highly polished and JJ to an accuracy of 1/100th of an inch , about 100 inches thick and weighing approx . 15 tons each . 06 . The cornerstone foundations of the pyramid have ball and socket construction capable of dealing with heat expansion and earthquakes . 07 . The mortar used is of an unknown origin ( Yes , no explanation given ) . It has been analyzed and its chemical composition is VBN but it ca n’t be reproduced . It is stronger than the stone and still holding up today . 08 . It was originally covered with casing stones ( made of highly polished limestone ) . These casing stones reflected the sun ’s light and made the pyramid shine IN a jewel . They are no longer present being used by Arabs to build mosques after an earthquake in the 14th century loosened JJ of them . It has been calculated that the original pyramid with its casing stones MD act IN gigantic mirrors and reflect light so powerful that it MD be visible from the moon as a shining star on NN . Appropriately , the ancient Egyptians called the Great Pyramid “ Ikhet ” , meaning the “ Glorious Light ” . How these blocks were transported and assembled into the pyramid is still a mystery . – http://www.gizapyramid.com/general.htm 09 . Aligned True North : The Great Pyramid is the most accurately aligned structure in existence and faces true north with only 3/60th of a degree of error . The position of the North Pole moves over NN and the pyramid was exactly aligned at CD NN . 10 . Center of Land Mass : The Great Pyramid is located at the center of the land mass of the NN . The east / west parallel that crosses the most land and the north / south meridian that crosses the most land intersect in CD places on the NN , CD in the NN and the other at the Great Pyramid . 11 . The four faces of the pyramid are slightly concave , the only pyramid to have been built this NN . 12 . The centers of the four sides are indented with an extraordinary degree of precision forming the only 8 sided pyramid , this effect is not visible from the ground or from a distance but only from the air , and then only under the proper lighting conditions . This phenomenon is only detectable from the air at dawn and sunset on the spring and autumn equinoxes , when the sun casts shadows on the pyramid . 13 . The granite coffer in the “ King ’s Chamber ” is too big to fit through the passages and so it must have been put in place during construction . 14 . The coffer was made out of a block of solid granite . This MD have required bronze saws 8 - 9 ft. JJ set with teeth of sapphires . Hollowing out of the interior MD require tubular drills of the same material applied with a tremendous vertical force . 15 . Microscopic analysis of the coffer reveals that it was made with a fixed point drill that used hard jewel bits and a drilling force of 2 tons . Related : The Real Builders of the Pyramids 16 . The Great Pyramid had a swivel door entrance at CD NN . Swivel doors were VBN in only CD other pyramids : Khufu ’s father and grandfather , Sneferu and Huni , respectively . 17 . It is reported that when the pyramid was RB broken into that the swivel door , weighing some 20 tons , was so well balanced that it MD be opened by pushing out from the inside with only minimal force , but when closed , was so perfect a fit that it MD scarcely be detected and there was not enough crack or crevice around the edges to gain a grasp from the outside . 18 . With the mantle in place , the Great Pyramid MD be seen from the mountains in Israel and probably the moon as well . CD . The weight of the pyramid is estimated at 5,955,000 tons . Multiplied by 10^8 gives a reasonable estimate of the NN ’s mass . 20 . The Descending Passage pointed to the pole star Alpha Draconis , circa 2170 - 2144 BCE . This was the North Star at that point in NN . No other star has aligned with the passage since then . 21 . The southern shaft in the King ’s Chamber pointed to the star Al Nitak ( Zeta Orionis ) in the constellation Orion , circa 2450 BCE The Orion constellation was associated with the Egyptian NN Osiris . No other star aligned with this shaft during that NN in history . 22 . Sun ’s Radius : Twice the perimeter of the bottom of the granite coffer times 10^8 is the sun ’s mean radius . [ 270.45378502 Pyramid Inches* 10^8 = 427,316 miles ] 23 . The curvature designed into the faces of the pyramid exactly matches the radius of the NN . 24 . Khufu ’s pyramid , VBN as the great pyramid of Giza , is the oldest and largest , rising at 481 NNS ( 146 meters ) . Archaeologists say it was the tallest structure in the NN for about 3 , 800 NNS . 25 . The relationship between Pi ( p ) and Phi ( F ) is expressed in the fundamental proportions of the Great Pyramid . text: Browsing through history , it ’s very clear that the NN has undergone JJ monumental shifts in society that have uprooted it ’s very foundation in place of JJ seed . A paradigm shift is a fundamental NN in approach or underlining assumptions . For example , when Pythagoras proposed that the NNP was round instead of JJ , the foundation of NN and NNS ’s understanding of the NN was completely changed . Similarly , when the Industrial Revolution took place there was a complete shift in manufacturing , lifestyle , and economics . A paradigm shift can literally shake a society to its core , taking it off its current path and putting it on a brand JJ NN . Though it might appear the opposite in the corporate controlled mainstream NN , it appears that the entire NN is in the very early stages of a paradigm shift . These shifts take place in JJ of the worlds most basic elements and redefine how NN functions . Here are 8 signs the NN is undergoing a paradigm shift : 1. The Power of the Internet and the Age of NN The Internet is arguably the greatest invention in the history of NN . Never in our VBN history has NN had access to such a broad range of diverse NN from all over the NN at the tips of his fingers . JJ forget that the Internet has only really been commercialized in the west since the early 1990 ’s and its spread across the NN has n’t RB come close to peaking yet . The Internet is undoubtedly giving rise to the Age of NN as NNS become more awake to what ’s really VBG on in the NN . A multitude of NN is now accessible if PRP knows where to look . NNS can now learn JJ skills or hear different versions of the NN in mere minutes . The Internet is not only giving rise to an open access of NN , but communication is almost instantaneous all over the NN . It is paramount that the Internet remain an open decentralized system in which everyone can freely add and operate if this paradigm shift is to continue . It feeds almost all other shifts . 2. The Ascent Of the Independent Non-Corporate Online NN Thanks solely to the Internet , the rise in independent journalism has taken off . Alternative NN has become an increasingly popular choice for those wishing to stay truly informed , especially younger generations . NNS are continually switching off cable NN ( cable TV all together ) , and instead resorting to online sources . While mainstream NN is still the number CD source of current NN events for the masses , the tide is slowly changing as NNS are awakening to the fact that corporate sponsored NN is mostly propaganda and half - truths . War is becoming much harder to justify as independent journalists have shined the light on what the powers that be never wanted anyone to VB . A prime example is the conflict in Syria in which the establishment , despite the lack of popular support , so desperately wanted to start a war that when the rebels they were funding used chemical weapons , it was then blamed on the Assad NN to protect their investment and design . Thanks to independent journalists , a war has so far been averted since it was revealed that the U.S. was in bed with the rebel groups and it was the rebels who used the chemical weapons . This JJ faction of journalism will give peace a legitimate chance as all dirty laundry is now being aired and corrupt alliances exposed . This in turn has allowed JJ NNS to deprogram from the countless NN they have taken in over the NNS and VB the NN through a clearer lens in which the NN is more evident . Though it will never be broadcast on mainstream NN , the real threat of a U.S. dollar collapse as the NN reserve currency is very real . The paradigm of central bank controlled economies that can issue credit and zero percent interest rates through nearly unlimited printing of money backed by nothing is an illusion that is beginning to break down . It ’s not just the U.S. dollar that ’s under threat , but JJ other central currencies such as the Euro and Yen . Massive equity bubbles are being blown up by this cheap credit along with massive debt that will be nearly impossible to pay RB with the current economies in which only the very elite benefit . JJ NNS are waking up to the fact that , IN all other bubbles , these bubbles will burst and they are beginning to break away from the dollar . Examples include the buildup of a JJ central bank in the emerging economy of the BRICS group , the countless NNS passing trade agreements in which bypassing the U.S. dollar ( including agreements in oil ) , and the persistent selling of treasury stocks by the Chinese NN who quite often are the last resort buyer of U.S. debt . Not only has there been a shift in the pecking order of fiat paper currencies , but decentralized crypto-currencies IN Bitcoin are threatening the very system of fiat money and the centralized NN a select few elite have on that system through central banks . This MD shift power worldwide . 4. The Rise of the Peer - to - Peer Economy A Peer - to - Peer ( P20 ) Economy is a de-centralized model whereby CD individuals interact to buy or sell goods and services directly with each other , without intermediation by a third - party , or without the use of a NN or business . We VBP this being used by NNS IN Air BnB , Uber , Craigslist , Sidecar , and Dogvacay among others . Often referred to as a sharing economy , there is no centralized NN of power , allowing NNS to more directly profit from their goods / services rather than pay unnecessary middlemen along the NN . This is a trend that is sure to grow as technology makes it easier for NNS to make it on their own and allows for NNS to own their means of production and finished goods , instead of just being paid in the production process . The peer - to - peer economy is RB possible through the abundance of goods already out there , allowing for goods to be shared and recycled rather than thrown away and reproduced . Not only is the peer - to - peer economy growing , but JJ young NNS are ditching the career 9 - 5 jobs and branching off into independent careers or job hopping . The top down business model in economics has now VBN a legitimate system in which a decentralized bottom up approach gives the power RB to the NNS . The shift towards renewable NN is a forgone conclusion as renewable NN is the NN of the future . In fact , the shift looks to be happening faster than NNS realize . According to the NNP NNP Initiative , “ Numerous scenarios projected levels of renewable NN for 2020 that already were surpassed by 2010 . ” The IEA VBZ that , “ In 2012 , the NN relied on renewable sources for around 13.2 % of its total primary NN supply , and in 2013 renewables accounted for almost 22 % of JJ electricity generation . ” With increased technological capabilities along with ever - growing concern over the NN of the environment , the NN is beginning to not only shift towards renewables , but the power over NN supplies and grids is decentralizing . For example , home solar panels or the JJ Tesla Powerwall , MD enable NNS to access their own NN directly from the sun without VBG through middlemen . Another example is a local city IN Burlington , VT being the JJ city in the U.S. to use 100 % renewable NN ; RB whole NNS IN Paraguay , Iceland and Norway being 100 % renewable . Cheap localized NN is on the horizon along with the very real possibility Nikola Teslaonce envisioned , which is a NN of free NN . The reemergence of organic food is not only on the rise , but the use of farmers markets and locally grown food is on the rise as well . According to the Non GMO project , “ In more than 60 NNS around the NN , including Australia , Japan , and all of the NNS in the European Union , there are significant restrictions or outright bans on the production and sale of GMOs . ” The rise is so strong that according to the Organic Trade Association , “ Supply shortages [ of organics ] are CD of the greatest challenges facing the industry today . Despite continued growth in production , handlers are not able to keep up with demand . ” Thanks in JJ part to the Internet and non-corporate sponsored NN , NNS are beginning to understand the importance behind knowing exactly what ’s in the food CD consumes and how it directly correlates to NN . This has put mounting pressure on food businesses to adapt . The signs are already evident as Chipotle sees their profits increase while operating completely Non-GMO , while sales giants such as McDonalds VBP profits continue to decrease amidst NN concerns over their food . JJ are beginning to truly care what goes into their NN and the rise of localized non-organic food in this country is a direct result of this NN - conscious shift . 7. text: Is a widespread NN outbreak inside the NNP NNPS inevitable ? After weeks of generally optimistic statements , officials are now warning us to prepare for the worst . Over the past several days we have seen the number of confirmed NNS outside of China escalate dramatically , and this has really rattled JJ financial markets . After being down more than 1,000 points on Monday , the Dow Jones Industrial Average fell another 879 points on Tuesday . U.S. stocks have lost more then 1.7 trillion dollars in value in just CD days . Much more importantly , a wave of tremendous panic is starting to sweep across America , and it looks IN this crisis is just getting started . Usually officials at the CDC choose their words very carefully so that they do not needlessly alarm the public . With that in mind , I MD VB for you to consider three statements that the CDC’s Dr. Nancy Messonnier made about a potential outbreak inside the NNP NNPS during a press conference on Tuesday … # 1 “ It ’s not so much of a question of if this will happen in this country anymore but a question of when this will happen . ” # 2 “ Disruption to everyday NN MD be severe . ” # 3 “ We are asking the American public to prepare for the expectation that this might be bad . ” Can you ever recall a top CDC official ever making statements this ominous ? In addition , Messonnier warned that it MD soon become necessary for schools and businesses to greatly restrict person to person contact … The CDC outlined what schools and businesses will likely need to do if the NN - CD NN becomes an epidemic outbreak in the U.S. Schools should consider dividing students into smaller groups or close and use “ internet - based tele - schooling , ” Dr. Nancy Messonnier , director of the CDC ’s National Center for Immunization and Respiratory Diseases , VBD reporters on a conference call . “ For adults , businesses can replace in - person meetings with NN or telephone conferences and increase teleworking options , ” Messonnier VBD . On a temporary basis such measures MD not be too disruptive , but what if this NN just keeps spreading month after month ? We are potentially facing a scenario that is truly unprecedented , and it is becoming increasingly clear that officials have lost confidence that they will be able to contain this NN . In fact , CD former U.S. official VBD USA Today that “ the horse is out of the barn ” … Dennis Carroll , former director of the U.S. Agency for International Development ’s NNP NNP Security and Development Unit , credited China ’s “ extraordinary NN measures ” with delaying the spread of the NN . But he VBD avoiding a NN is “ very unlikely . ” “ The dramatic uptick of NNS in South Korea , Iran and Italy are reflective of a self - sustaining spreading of the NN , ” Carroll , who now leads the NNP Virome Project NN cooperative , VBD USA TODAY . “ And a clear message that the horse is out of the barn . ” At this point there are still only a few dozen confirmed NNS in the NNP NNPS , but authorities are bracing for the worst . If you can VB it , San Francisco Mayor London Breed just declared a NN of emergency because of this NN … Mayor London Breed declared a local emergency in San Francisco Tuesday amid the NN outbreak , despite there being no confirmed NNS among the city ’s residents . “ Although there are still zero confirmed NNS in San Francisco residents , the JJ picture is changing rapidly , and we need to step - up preparedness , ” Breed VBD in a statement . “ We VBP the NN spreading in JJ parts of the NN every day , and we are taking the necessary steps to protect San Franciscans from harm . ” And after being quite apathetic about this outbreak at RB , NNS all over America are suddenly realizing that they should be preparing for a potential NN . In fact , Silicon Valley investor Geoff Lewis created quite a stir when he asked for advice on stockpiling food . The following is the question that he posted on NNP that caused so much of an uproar … If CD were hypothetically stockpiling four months of shelf stable food , what MD folks recommend ( optimizing for keto friendly ) ? We have n’t seen anything IN this in the NNP NNPS in a very JJ NN . But we have n’t RB had a single death from this NN in our country yet . How crazed will NNS VB when victims start dropping dead in the streets IN they have been in Wuhan ? There is now talk that the IOC MD potentially cancel or postpone the Olympic Games in Tokyo . At CD NN such talk MD have seemed crazy , but this is how serious this outbreak has become . In Iran , the number of confirmed NNS has now jumped to 95 , although JJ NNS VBP that the true number is far , far higher . During a press conference on Monday , Iran ’s deputy NN minister attempted to downplay the seriousness of this outbreak , but on Tuesday we learned that he has been infected too … Iran ’s deputy NN minister VBD he has tested positive for the novel NN and is in self - quarantine at his home just a day after he appeared at a NN conference in Tehran where he sought to quell fears about the outbreak . Iraj Harirchi , the head of Iran ’s counter - NN task force , announced the illness in a NN online while vowing that authorities MD continue working to VB the spread . Apparently not wanting to be outdone , CD of the officials in South Korea that was overseeing the response to this outbreak decided to jump off a bridge … But in Seoul took on a more morbid tone Tuesday following reports in the local press that a civil servant from the Ministry of Justice ’s Emergency Safety Planning Office jumped off a bridge in Seoul at around 5 am local NN Tuesday . The official was CD of several individuals charged with overseeing the NN ’s response to the NN . As NNS soar and hysteria mounts , we suspect this NN wo n’t exactly VB quiet the public ’s nerves . Suicide is never the answer to anything , and we should all be praying for that NN ’s family . In Italy , the number of confirmed NNS has grown by more than 15 times since Friday … Over in Italy , the number of confirmed NNS has surpassed 300 to 322 , while the number of dead climbed to 10 , according to Italian emergency chief Angelo Borrelli , who VBD the newly deceased were over the age of 80 . That ’s up from just 20 confirmed NNS on Friday . Newly deceased were over 80 NNS old , VBZ at press conference in Rome Tuesday . The JJ infections include three NNS in southern Sicily region , Italian Civil Protection official Borrelli VBD . All of a sudden , NNS all over Europe are wanting to avoid Italians because of the potential of catching the NN . In most NNS that fear is irrational , but we do VB that an Italian just spread the NN to a hotel in Spain ’s Canary Islands … Hundreds of staff and tourists staying at a hotel in Spain ’s Canary Islands were put under lockdown on Tuesday , El Pais newspaper reported . CD person who had stayed at the establishment was later VBN to have tested positive for the NN . I lived in Italy for a few NNS as a NN , and I have a great love for the country . It is so sad to watch what is happening over there , but the same things are VBG to start happening here . In fact , Dr. Messonnier has VBN the public that now is the NN “ to begin preparing ” for a massive outbreak … “ NNS are concerned about this situation – I MD say rightfully so , ” Messonnier VBD . “ But we are putting our concerns to work preparing . Now is the NN for businesses , hospitals , communities , schools and everyday NNS to begin preparing as well . ” If you do prepare and all of this turns out to be a false alarm , at least you will be ready for the next crisis that is coming . But if you do n’t do anything to prepare and things VBP really , really bad , it MD end up costing you dearly . If this NN starts spreading across the NNP NNPS IN wildfire , you and your family will VB to minimize contact with the public as much as possible . So stock up on the things you will need now , because when things start getting really crazy the stores will be cleaned out very quickly . NN spreads to Germany , Switzerland , Croatia , Iraq , Spain , Algeria , Austria and Brazil while NNS explode in Italy by 45 % in CD day Over the last 36 hours or so , the NN spread has now been confirmed in a slew of JJ NNS , including Germany , Switzerland , Croatia , Iraq , Spain , Algeria and Austria . NNS are already confirmed in Belgium , Lebanon , Finland , Sweden , Egypt , Sri Lanka , Israel , Cambodia , Nepal , Afghanistan , Russia and JJ other NNS . An infection is now suspected in Brazil , which MD make it the JJ South American nation to confirm a NN infection , bringing the NN to a whole JJ continent . According to Brazil ’s NNP Ministry , CD test of a local patient has reportedly come RB positive . A second confirmation test is necessary to make the diagnosis “ official . ” These are irrefutable facts , yet we still have naysayers throughout the NN and across the cultural landscape who claim none of this is happening , that the NN bioweapon system is “ just another NN , ” or that it ’s a grand hoax being perpetrated by all these NNS as some elaborate staged event to commit JJ suicide for some unknown reason . NN denialism is essentially the “ NNP NNP ” version of epidemiology . According to the denialists , all the nations listed above are faking it , sacrificing their national economics to carry out some sort of elaborate hoax for some unimaginable reason . Rush Limbaugh , meanwhile , still insists the NN is just “ the NN . ” It ’s a reminder why highly influential NNS should stick to their areas of expertise and not wander into areas where they very quickly demonstrate their shocking technical ignorance and lack of knowledge . NN infections exploded overnight in Italy , rising to 322 confirmed NNS , an increase of 100 from the previous day . To try to stop the spread of the NN , Italy is running armed road blocks surrounding 12 towns , prohibiting road travel . According to The Epoch Times , no NN in Italy RB knows the source of the outbreak , completely obliterating any argument from WHO officials that this is “ contained ” or “ not a NN . ” Via TET : Italian NN officials have n’t yet identified the source of the outbreak . Angelo Borrelli , the head of the Italian civil protection department , VBD the case count grew from 222 to 322 , representing a 45 % increase , in a 24 - hour period from Monday evening to Tuesday evening . According to the NN denialists , of course , Italy must be faking it for some reason . Yes , it ’s an insane idea , but that ’s what is now being promoted by the left - wing NN and RB some conservative journalists . Notably , the very bureaucrat in Iran who VBD everybody the NN was no big deal is now infected himself . RB via TET : Only a day earlier , a coughing and heavily sweating Iraj Harirchi VBD at a televised NN conference in Tehran that “ the situation is almost stable in the country . ” NNP Ministry spokesman Kianoush Jahanpour confirmed Harirchi had the NN . Harirchi himself posted an online NN saying he had it and that he had quarantined himself at home . He promised that authorities MD bring the NN under NN . That ’s reassuring , huh ? The very NN bureaucrat sitting in quarantine after accidentally getting infected is telling us all the NN has it under NN . The irony is almost pure comedy , if it were n’t so tragic . San Franciso declares NN of emergency while NN tells us there ’s no emergency at all San Francisco , meanwhile , has just declared a NN of emergency over the NN , RB when CDC officials claim there are essentially zero confirmed NNS in San Francisco . According to the SF Chronicle , Mayor London Breed VBD more resources need to be allocated , “ to make sure we are prepared , ” RB while the entire NN establishment in America claims there ’s nothing to be prepared for in the JJ place . So why did San Fran just declare an emergency , then ? The CDC ’s insane policy of “ Do n’t Test , Do n’t Tell ” is keeping America in the dark while the epidemic explodes across U.S. cities .

text: Mining towns draw monikers from it . Political leaders keep close tabs on it . Others VBP out disparage it . Indeed , uranium owns its share of controversy . For NNS , the element has been tied to talk of nuclear weapons and the birth of the atomic age . Today , however , the metal has taken on a different role -- in the form of NN . In fact , much of the enriched uranium stored in nuclear weapons from the arms race has been rededicated to fueling the NN 's nuclear power reactors , which provided the NN with almost 14 percent of its electricity in 2010 [ source : Nuclear NNP Institute ] . And it 's extremely powerful , too . CD 7 - gram pellet of uranium fuel produces as much NN as 3.5 barrels of oil and 807 kilograms ( 1,779 pounds ) of coal [ source : Newfoundland Labrador DNR ] . Beyond lighting up homes and businesses through nuclear power , uranium makes radioisotopes that produce radiation , which can VB diagnose and treat certain medical conditions . It 's RB used for shielding and , in its depleted form , as counterweights for aircraft , too . But where does uranium come from and how is it gathered ? IN other metals , uranium occurs naturally in rocks on the NNP 's NN and can be extracted through uranium mining . Miners originally discovered uranium alongside radium , another element that was used as glowing , decorative paint ( at least until NNS realized its harmful , radioactive effects ) . Uranium hit the market as a decorative glaze before its nuclear properties were discovered . This heavy metal comes in several isotopes , or forms of the element with different numbers of neutrons . Depending on the stability of an isotope , some can be more radioactive ( likely to give off energetic particles ) and fissile ( likely to produce nuclear fission ) than others . Uranium - 238 measures as the most abundant isotope of the element on NNP and can be VBN in rocks and seawater . But it 's not as radioactive as uranium - 235 , the best - VBN form of uranium used to create nuclear reactions . In this article , we 'll chart the uranium mining process , tracking the element as it transitions from ore to fuel pellets ready to be used by nuclear reactors . We 'll RB look at the wax and wane of uranium mining , as well as the risks for humans and the environment by following the contentious debate over mining uranium in the backyard of the U.S. 's most iconic canyon . Dust off your doomsday clock as we revisit the origins of uranium mining and all things nuclear on the next page .

text: As investigators search for the NN who they say set a small fire last week at D.C. - area pizza shop , Comet Ping Pong , followers of the debunked " NN " NN NN have been speculating about what was " really " behind the blaze . " To destroy evidence or vengeance ? I hope the latter , " a user wrote on the public NNP group " PizzagateUncompromised , " CD of hundreds of comments in dozens of NNP groups dedicated to the NN NN . In CD group , users responded to NN that Comet pizza was on fire with gifs of NNS eating popcorn . Others just celebrated . " Burn baby burn that evil place of debauchery of NNS , torture and murder down , " CD user wrote . NNP — which alleged that Hillary NNP and prominent Democrats ran a NN NN and sacrifice ring out of the pizzeria 's basement — has mostly waned since its nadir in December 2016 , when a North Carolina NN on a mission to rescue imaginary NNS fired several shots from an assault - style rifle inside the restaurant . Eclipsed by a related NN NN , Qanon , NN has decreased in popularity in part due to crackdowns by online platforms . Reddit banned the NN groups in 2016 and NNP recently announced a commitment to stop recommending NN videos . But they still have a home on NNP . In over 30 different open and closed NNP groups , boasting more than 40,000 collective members , NN followers have kept the NN alive . In the face of reason , these NN adherents have held tightly to " evidence " — mostly what they allege is coded language and symbols that link shapes to pedophelia and food products IN cheese and pasta to NNS . The members post misinformation and wild allegations linking just about anyone to a NN - wide pedopehila ring . Their targets have included everyone and everything from local businesses to Tom Hanks to a random NNP user wearing a t - shirt with the image of a slice of pizza on it . This week , a major topic of conversation has been Celine Dion 's weight loss , which group members falsely attributed to an addiction to Adrenochrome , a real chemical compound that NN conspiracists claim is " harvested " from tortured NNS , and taken by the political and Hollywood elite to VB high . None of this is borne out by any evidence to be true in any NN . In 2018 , NNP CEO Mark Zuckerberg announced the platform was refocusing the Newsfeed so that users MD VB less content from NN and brands and more from their friends , family and groups . For the majority of NNP users , that meant more posts from local parent collectives , spread out family groups , or RB - minded hobbyists . For the more conspiratorial user , it can amount to a curated cult . It 's not merely the existence of NN - IN NN groups , but the mechanisms by which NNP serves them up , that can radicalize users , VBD Renée DiResta , a researcher of disinformation online and director of NN at NNP Knowledge . Joining a NNP group tells NNP to suggest other groups and pages related to the topic . " If you VBP something , it will show you more of that , " DiResta VBD . " So belonging to gardening groups will make NNP suggest to you more gardening groups . " NNP 's suggestion algorithm RB infers commonalities between users and other members of groups that user joins . " In a healthy NN , this MD mean NNP is saying ' If you VBP gardening , maybe you RB VBP cooking , ' " DiResta VBD . " In the case of NN content , NNP 's recommendation engine VBZ , ' If you VBP pseudoscience , I 'll show you chemtrails and JJ NN . ' " " Because of the increase of ominous conspiracies , you 're seeing groups around these NN theories IN QAnon or NN being referred to NNS who MD never search for them in the JJ place . " As an example , for users who find their NN into a NN interest group named after Hillary NNP 's NN chairman , John Podesta — whose stolen emails are misread in a NN to inform much of the NNP NN — a JJ rail labeled " Suggested Groups " includes the group " NNP Reports , " the header image for which is prominent Democrats including Hillary NNP and Barack Obama and George Soros , photoshopped with glowing red eyes in what appears to be a Satanic ritual . Similarly , users visiting the private group " NNP , " topped with an image that points to Comet 's owner James Alefantis as the ringleader of a NN sacrifice ring — are pushed to join other fringe groups including , " Real UFO Sightings & Strange Phenomenon , " " Official NNP NNP & Globe Discussion , " and " Q Angels , " a group dedicated to an unfounded NN NN involving Donald NNP and a secret war against a cabal of alleged NN abusers . NNP did not respond to a request for comment . In a July interview with Recode editor Kara Swisher , CEO Mark Zuckerberg defended the practice of letting NN groups remain , but acknowledged NNP 's responsibility to take down misinformation that MD induce violence . Alefantis VBD The Washington Post that the shop still regularly gets harassing phone calls , a practice discussed in several of the NN NNP Groups . " At JJ [ the manager ] VBD I was making him physically shake and now he just listens to me until he finally hangs up . He never really answers or addresses my concerns . But I still call . Once a day , every day , " CD woman wrote last NN under a post about her efforts to call Comet regularly . " Love it !! Lol VB em , " another user responded .

text: The headline for Thomas L. Friedman 's insightful article is meaningful in another sense ( April 3 ) . I refer to the increasing encroachment of religious extremism and biblical literalism into the realm of NN . RB in biology , then spreading to physics and onward , it seems there are forces at work trying to bring us RB to the JJ NN of the Middle Ages . IN Galileo , we are in the midst of a battle between scientific progress and dogmatic belief . Is there any better gift we MD hand to the rising scientific forces in China and India than the compromising of our future scientific achievements in this manner ? text: Investor Warren Buffett MD be more comfortable with fellow billionaire Michael Bloomberg winning the Democratic presidential nomination than front - runner Bernie Sanders . “ ‘ I do n’t VB another billionaire supporting him MD be the best thing to announce . But sure , I MD …have no trouble voting for Mike Bloomberg ’ ” That is Buffett in an interview with CNBC on Monday morning when the Berkshire Hathaway BRK.A , BRK.B , chairman and chief executive , was pressed on a Democratic presidential race that ’s seen Sanders , a Vermont socialist , take an early lead in the race to the nomination . Unlike Lloyd Blankfein , the former Goldman Sachs chief who has engaged in a bitter war of words with Sanders to the senator ’s apparent delight , Buffett VBD Sanders has raised some valid issues . Keywords : Ex -Goldman boss Lloyd Blankfein ‘ might find it harder to vote for Bernie ’ than for NNP “ I MD say this in terms of Sanders , I actually agree with him in terms of certain things he MD VB to accomplish . I do n’t agree with him in JJ ways . But in terms of the fact that we ought to do better by the NNS that VBP left behind by our capitalist system . I do n’t VB we should kill the capitalist system in the process , ” Buffett VBD . Buffett , who backed Hillary NNP ’s presidential candidacy in 2016 , VBD he MD n’t attempt to handicap the race for the nomination , but VBD that “ if given a choice , I MD certainly vote for Mike Bloomberg as opposed to Sanders . ” Stocks were down sharply on Monday as worries about the spread of NN - CD outside China sparked a JJ equity rout . The Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA , was down more than 1,000 points in afternoon trade . The blue - chip gauge and the S&P 500 SPX , were both off more than 3 % on the day . text: Speakers recently flew in from around ( or perhaps , across ? ) the NNP for a three - day event held in Birmingham : the UK ’s JJ ever public JJ NNP convention . It was well attended , and was n’t just three days of speeches and NNP clips ( though , granted , there was a lot of this ) . There was RB a lot of team - building , networking , debating , workshops – and scientific experiments . Yes , JJ earthers do seem to place a lot of emphasis and priority on scientific methods and , in particular , on observable facts . The weekend , in no small part , revolved around discussing and debating NN , with lots of NN spent running , planning , and reporting on the latest set of JJ NNP experiments and models . Indeed , as CD presenter noted early on , JJ earthers try to “ look for multiple , verifiable evidence ” and advised attendees to “ always do your own NN and accept you might be wrong ” . While JJ earthers seem to trust and support scientific methods , what they do n’t trust is NNS , and the established relationships between “ power ” and “ knowledge ” . This relationship between power and knowledge has RB been theorised by sociologists . By exploring this relationship , we can begin to understand why there is a swelling resurgence of JJ earthers . Let me begin by stating quickly that I ’m not really interested in discussing if the NNP is JJ or not ( for the record , I ’m happily a “ globe earther ” ) – and I ’m not seeking to mock or denigrate this community . What ’s important here is not necessarily whether they VBP the NNP is JJ or not , but instead what their resurgence and public conventions , such as the NN in Birmingham , tell us about NN and knowledge in the 21st century . Multiple competing models were suggested throughout the weekend , including “ classic ” JJ NN , domes , NN walls , diamonds , puddles with multiple worlds inside , and RB the NNP as the inside of a giant cosmic egg . The level of discussion however often did not revolve around the models on offer , but on broader issues of attitudes towards existing structures of knowledge , and the institutions that supported and presented these models . JJ earthers are not the JJ group to be sceptical of existing power structures and their tight grasps on knowledge . This viewpoint is somewhat typified by the work of Michel Foucault , a famous and heavily influential 20th century philosopher who made a career of studying those on the fringes of society to understand what they MD tell us about everyday NN . He is well VBN , among JJ other things , for looking at the close relationship between power and knowledge . He suggested that knowledge is created and used in a NN that reinforces the claims to legitimacy of those in power . At the same NN , those in power VBP what is considered to be correct and incorrect knowledge . According to Foucault , there is therefore an intimate and interlinked relationship between power and knowledge . At the NN Foucault was writing on the topic , the NN of power and knowledge had moved away from religious institutions , which previously had a very singular hold over knowledge and morality , and was instead beginning to move towards a network of scientific institutions , NN monopolies , legal courts , and bureaucratised governments . Foucault argued that these institutions work to maintain their claims to legitimacy by controlling knowledge . In the 21st century , we are witnessing another important shift in both power and knowledge due to factors that include the increased availability of public platforms afforded by JJ NN . Knowledge is no longer centrally controlled and – as has been pointed out in the wake of Brexit – the age of the expert MD be passing . Now , everybody has the power to create and share content . When Michael Gove , a leading proponent of Brexit , proclaimed : “ I VBP the NNS of this country have had enough of experts ” , it MD seem that he , in JJ ways , meant it . It is RB clear that we ’re seeing increased polarisation in society , as we continue to drift away from agreed singular narratives and move into camps around shared interests . Recent PEW NN suggests , for example , that 80 per cent of voters who backed Hillary NNP in the 2016 US presidential election – and 81 per cent of NNP voters – VB most supporters of the CD candidates are unable to agree on basic facts , let alone policies . Despite early claims , from as far RB as HG Wells ’s NNP Brain essays in 1936 , that a worldwide , shared resource of knowledge , such as the internet , MD create peace , harmony and a common interpretation of reality , it appears that quite the opposite has happened . With the increased voice afforded by JJ NN to a wide range of views , knowledge has been increasingly decentralised , and competing narratives have emerged . This was something of a recurring theme throughout the weekend in Birmingham , and was especially apparent when four JJ earthers debated three physics PhD students . A particular point of contention occurred when CD of the physicists pleaded with the audience to avoid trusting NNP and bloggers . The audience and the panel of JJ earthers took exception to this , noting that “ now we ’ve got the internet and mass communication … we ’re not reliant on what the mainstream are telling us in newspapers , we can decide for ourselves ” . It was readily apparent that the JJ earthers were keen to separate knowledge from scientific institutions . At the same NN as scientific claims to knowledge and power are being undermined , some power structures are decoupling themselves from scientific knowledge , moving towards a kind of populist politics that is increasingly sceptical of knowledge . This has , in recent NNS , manifested itself in extreme ways – and can be seen in such examples as public figures showing support for NNP or NNP ’s suggestions that Ted Cruz ’s father shot JFK . But it can RB be seen in more subtle and insidious forms : in the NN in which Brexit , for example , was campaigned for in terms of gut feelings and emotions rather than expert statistics and predictions . NN is increasingly facing problems with its ability to communicate ideas publicly , a problem that JJ earthers , and politicians , are able to circumvent with moves towards populism . Again , this theme occurred throughout the weekend . JJ earthers were encouraged to trust “ poetry , freedom , passion , vividness , creativity , and yearning ” over the more clinical regurgitation of established theories and facts . Attendees were VBN that “ hope VBZ everything ” , and were warned against blindly trusting what they were VBN . This is a narrative echoed by some of the celebrities who have used their power to VB JJ NNP beliefs , such as the musician BOB , who tweeted : “ Do n’t VB what I say , VB what I say . ” In JJ ways , a public meeting of JJ earthers is a product and sign of our NN ; a reflection of our increasing distrust in scientific institutions , and the moves by power - holding institutions towards populism and emotions . In much the same NN that Foucault reflected on what JJ outcasts MD reveal about our JJ systems , there is a lot that JJ earthers can reveal to us about the current changing relationship between power and knowledge . And judging by the success of this UK event – and the JJ conventions planned in Canada and America this NN – it seems the JJ NNP is VBG to be around for a while yet . Harry T Dyer is a lecturer in education at the NN of East Anglia . This piece originally appeared on The Conversation ( theconversation.com )
